Genesis 27 35 But he said, "Your brother came deceitfully and took your blessing." 36 Esau said, "Isn't he rightly named Jacob [1] ? He has deceived me these two times: He took my birthright, and now he's taken my blessing!" Then he asked, "Haven't you reserved any blessing for me?" 37 Isaac answered Esau, "I have made him lord over you and have made all his relatives his servants, and I have sustained him with grain and new wine. So what can I possibly do for you, my son?" 38 Esau said to his father, "Do you have only one blessing, my father? Bless me too, my father!" Then Esau wept aloud. 39 His father Isaac answered him, "Your dwelling will be away from the earth's richness, away from the dew of heaven above. 40 You will live by the sword and you will serve your brother. But when you grow restless, you will throw his yoke from off your neck." Jacob Flees to Laban 41 Esau held a grudge against Jacob because of the blessing his father had given him. He said to himself, "The days of mourning for my father are near; then I will kill my brother Jacob." AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAARGH!! My brother Jacob is such a pain! That TWIT! Mother's boy. I should have known he and Mom were plotting against me! She's always sided with him. He takes my birthright for a bowl of soup, and now he steals my blessings. It isn't fair! -Esau- No, Esau didn't say that. I was making that up. Still, I imagine that's what it felt like, only a thousand times worse. If you ask me, Jacob deserves to be tied up and thrown into a lake of dung beetles, or something. Esau was the elder brother, and had the right to his father's land, servants, wealth and blessings. If you don't know the story, here's how it goes: [If you do, just skip the passage] Jacob Gets Isaac's Blessing 1 When Isaac was old and his eyes were so weak that he could no longer see, he called for Esau his older son and said to him, "My son." "Here I am," he answered. 2 Isaac said, "I am now an old man and don't know the day of my death. 3 Now then, get your weapons-your quiver and bow-and go out to the open country to hunt some wild game for me. 4 Prepare me the kind of tasty food I like and bring it to me to eat, so that I may give you my blessing before I die." 5 Now Rebekah was listening as Isaac spoke to his son Esau. When Esau left for the open country to hunt game and bring it back, 6 Rebekah said to her son Jacob, "Look, I overheard your father say to your brother Esau, 7 'Bring me some game and prepare me some tasty food to eat, so that I may give you my blessing in the presence of the LORD before I die.' 8 Now, my son, listen carefully and do what I tell you: 9 Go out to the flock and bring me two choice young goats, so I can prepare some tasty food for your father, just the way he likes it. 10 Then take it to your father to eat, so that he may give you his blessing before he dies." 11 Jacob said to Rebekah his mother, "But my brother Esau is a hairy man, and I'm a man with smooth skin. 12 What if my father touches me? I would appear to be tricking him and would bring down a curse on myself rather than a blessing." 13 His mother said to him, "My son, let the curse fall on me. Just do what I say; go and get them for me." 14 So he went and got them and brought them to his mother, and she prepared some tasty food, just the way his father liked it. 15 Then Rebekah took the best clothes of Esau her older son, which she had in the house, and put them on her younger son Jacob. 16 She also covered his hands and the smooth part of his neck with the goatskins. 17 Then she handed to her son Jacob the tasty food and the bread she had made. 18 He went to his father and said, "My father." "Yes, my son," he answered. "Who is it?" 19 Jacob said to his father, "I am Esau your firstborn. I have done as you told me. Please sit up and eat some of my game so that you may give me your blessing." 20 Isaac asked his son, "How did you find it so quickly, my son?" "The LORD your God gave me success," he replied. 21 Then Isaac said to Jacob, "Come near so I can touch you, my son, to know whether you really are my son Esau or not." 22 Jacob went close to his father Isaac, who touched him and said, "The voice is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau." 23 He did not recognize him, for his hands were hairy like those of his brother Esau; so he blessed him. 24 "Are you really my son Esau?" he asked. "I am," he replied. 25 Then he said, "My son, bring me some of your game to eat, so that I may give you my blessing." Jacob brought it to him and he ate; and he brought some wine and he drank. 26 Then his father Isaac said to him, "Come here, my son, and kiss me." 27 So he went to him and kissed him. When Isaac caught the smell of his clothes, he blessed him and said,... Ever been so angry at someone you could just kill her?[him?] I have sooo been there. God is unfathomable sometimes. Really, He works in twisted, absurd ways that no one in his human mind could comprehend. Reading about Esau and Jacob, you'd think that Jacob would get punished later on in the story, right? Just like you can't help wishing that your enemies would get trodden by a God-sent elephant. Well *ding!* Guess what? Jacob was the one who lived happily ever after. Jacob was the one who saw a vision of angels in heaven. Jacob married Rebecca. (admittedly, he earned it). Jacob had the honour of being Jesus' great-great-great-great-great-great grandfather. Instead of using Esau who was wronged to beget the world's Saviour, God used Jacob, the deceiver. As much as we don't want to look at the possibilty that God might have awesome plans for our enemies, it's there. In the end, Esau forgave Jacob, and hugged him at the end of this tale. After many years, but still! And we should forgive too, because if Jesus died for the forgiveness of our sins, we should forgive others when they wrong us. It may be crazy talk, offering your other cheek when you're slapped, but hey, that's what God says. Signing off, Jenna

Matthew 5 Love for Enemies 43"You have heard that it was said, 'Love your neighbor and hate your enemy.' 44But I tell you: Love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you, 45that you may be sons of your Father in heaven. He causes his sun to rise on the evil and the good, and sends rain on the righteous and the unrighteous. 46If you love those who love you, what reward will you get? Are not even the tax collectors doing that? 47And if you greet only your brothers, what are you doing more than others? Do not even pagans do that? 48Be perfect, therefore, as your heavenly Father is perfect. The teachings of Jesus sometimes seem inapplicable in the world we live in. We know His teachings are certainly right, but in this day and age they sometimes seem unpractical and occasionaly, even crazy. Seriously, how much sense does it make to love those who hate you? It doesn't seem logical to ask God to bless the people who talk bad about you, hurt you, and walk all over you. But have you ever thought about how love can diffuse a situation? When being shouted at, your enemy expects you to fight back (and has probably thought of a reply to what he thinks you're going to say). What do you think would happen if you showed love to someone who was antagonizing you? Imagine hugging the person shouting at you, he'd be at a lost for words and you'd effectively win the argument, or at least diffuse it. Verse 45 tells us why we should follow Jesus' teachings. It's for a higher purpose, so we can be called God's children. People on earth may laugh and wonder why we act the way we do, but the bottomline is Jesus has instructed us to do it. We're called to love everyone, but the passage talks specifically about loving your enemies. It's so easy to love the person who bought you the Belle & Sebastian album you've been looking for for months, but how easy is it to love the person who borrowed and lost it? Anyone can love someone who loves them in return (we should still do this of course), but Jesus' special instructions involve loving the unlovable. Of all the things on earth, love is surely the most powerful. It's what (in theory) distinguishes Christians, and it's what we should always use on others. In tense situations, if you don't love, anything else you do has the potential to blow up in your face. Your friend, Kevin

Job 9 1 Then Job replied: 2 "Indeed, I know that this is true. But how can a mortal be righteous before God? 3 Though one wished to dispute with him, he could not answer him one time out of a thousand. 4 His wisdom is profound, his power is vast. Who has resisted him and come out unscathed? 5 He moves mountains without their knowing it and overturns them in his anger. 6 He shakes the earth from its place and makes its pillars tremble. 7 He speaks to the sun and it does not shine; he seals off the light of the stars. 8 He alone stretches out the heavens and treads on the waves of the sea. 9 He is the Maker of the Bear and Orion, the Pleiades and the constellations of the south. 10 He performs wonders that cannot be fathomed, miracles that cannot be counted." When I get depressed with the state of the world, I find the best thing to do is to take a good look around. In the simple things, you can often find joy in recognizing God's miracles. My all-time top five simple wonders that remind me of God: Seeing the sunset in the distance, usually when it's spectacularly orange. Being caught in the rain. It's when I can feel things I'm not usually able to. Stars at night, even if some of them are satellites. Dolphins. Never seen one in real life, only on the Discovery Channel. The smile on the face of a friend when his/her day has suddenly become fine. There's so many things that we should be able to smile about knowing that it's one of God's miracles. Footnotes 2:6 Or in the form of 2:7 Or the form Jesus told his disciples that whoever wants to be the greatest must be the least.Jesus, King of Kings, was the greatast servant of all. 2 Timothy 1 1Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, according to the promise of life that is in Christ Jesus, 2To Timothy, my dear son: Grace, mercy and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord. Encouragement to Be Faithful 3I thank God, whom I serve, as my forefathers did, with a clear conscience, as night and day I constantly remember you in my prayers. 4Recalling your tears, I long to see you, so that I may be filled with joy. 5I have been reminded of your sincere faith, which first lived in your grandmother Lois and in your mother Eunice and, I am persuaded, now lives in you also. 6For this reason I remind you to fan into flame the gift of God, which is in you through the laying on of my hands. 7For God did not give us a spirit of timidity, but a spirit of power, of love and of self-discipline. 2 Timothy 2 1You then, my son, be strong in the grace that is in Christ Jesus. 2And the things you have heard me say in the presence of many witnesses entrust to reliable men who will also be qualified to teach others. When you think about it, how do Christians come about? I mean, they don't just simply 'exist', they surely had to have gone through a process of becoming a Christian. So then, how are Christians made? Obviously, God makes Christians. What I mean is, the final decision of someone to be a true Christian comes from God's conviction. Of course, there's still free choice for everyone when it comes to this. But there are other things that help bring people to know Christ. Some people are born into a Christian family and believing for them is a gradual process. Some people come to know Christ through a dramatic chain of events. Either way, there's always other people involved in someone's Christian journey. In 2 Timothy, it's clear that Timothy was helped along in his faith by his mother, grandmother, and even Paul. Many people come to know God through the efforts of parents, friends, pastors, and anyone God can make use of. For a person born into a Christian family, his parents play an important role from a young age. A non-believer may be brought to Christ through the words and actions of a close friend. I'm certain we can identify people who have helped us along in our walk with God. Everyone knows these people, so it's obvious that we should be these people as well. As Christians, we're in a position to help so many others know the God whom we believe in. When we see how much of our faith is due to people who have helped us, we should feel the urge to help others in the same way. Your friend, Kevin

Deuteronomy 32 44 Moses came with Joshua son of Nun and spoke all the words of this song in the hearing of the people. 45 When Moses finished reciting all these words to all Israel, 46 he said to them, "Take to heart all the words I have solemnly declared to you this day, so that you may command your children to obey carefully all the words of this law. 47 They are not just idle words for you-they are your life. By them you will live long in the land you are crossing the Jordan to possess." 48 On that same day the LORD told Moses, 49 "Go up into the Abarim Range to Mount Nebo in Moab, across from Jericho, and view Canaan, the land I am giving the Israelites as their own possession. 50 There on the mountain that you have climbed you will die and be gathered to your people, just as your brother Aaron died on Mount Hor and was gathered to his people. 51 This is because both of you broke faith with me in the presence of the Israelites at the waters of Meribah Kadesh in the Desert of Zin and because you did not uphold my holiness among the Israelites. 52 Therefore, you will see the land only from a distance; you will not enter the land I am giving to the people of Israel." I turned seventeen yesterday. For the past week, I've been going through a 'mid-life' crisis, feeling so lost. I've never felt so old and so young at the same time. You see, I was sixteen last year, which means I'm now past the midway point of my teenage years (you do the math). At the same time, it was only seven years ago that I was ten. I expected that with growing older, I'd actually feel grown up. As it turned out, God has blessed me tremendously. On my birthday, things happened which enabled me to look past all my fears and insecurities, and see that I have so much in my life. After thinking about things for awhile, it's easy to see that when everything seems to fall apart God is still looking out for us, all the while knowing how much we can take. When God told Moses he was going to die (imagine being told something like that and knowing it would happen), Moses still praised God until the day he died. It can become so easy to think it's all going downhill as we edge closer to death. Though for us, it's normally ageing and nothing as dramatic as an anouncement of death. It should be equally easy to look at the future positively. Ever read the book 'Tuesdays with Morrie'? It's about this professor who suffers from an illness and is going to die. Before he dies, he imparts life's lessons to one of his former students. This book has gained loads of praise for the way it faces death. Personally, I think the book presents a misguided view of death. The dying man doesn't know God, so while he talks very sensibly about how we should live life, it's still not enough. There's no hope in facing death without God no matter how smart we are. The future is an uncertain thing that scares me to death. The only way to face growing old is with faith in God. In the past week, I've learned you can't stop growing old. What you can do (with eyes firmly on God and people you love around you), is age gracefully. Your friend, Kevin

Daniel 4 The Dream Is Fulfilled 28 All this happened to King Nebuchadnezzar. 29 Twelve months later, as the king was walking on the roof of the royal palace of Babylon, 30 he said, "Is not this the great Babylon I have built as the royal residence, by my mighty power and for the glory of my majesty?" 31 The words were still on his lips when a voice came from heaven, "This is what is decreed for you, King Nebuchadnezzar: Your royal authority has been taken from you. 32 You will be driven away from people and will live with the wild animals; you will eat grass like cattle. Seven times will pass by for you until you acknowledge that the Most High is sovereign over the kingdoms of men and gives them to anyone he wishes." 33 Immediately what had been said about Nebuchadnezzar was fulfilled. He was driven away from people and ate grass like cattle. His body was drenched with the dew of heaven until his hair grew like the feathers of an eagle and his nails like the claws of a bird. 34 At the end of that time, I, Nebuchadnezzar, raised my eyes toward heaven, and my sanity was restored. Then I praised the Most High; I honored and glorified him who lives forever. His dominion is an eternal dominion; his kingdom endures from generation to generation. 35 All the peoples of the earth are regarded as nothing. God was angry with Nebby's pride, and what Nebby suffered next just about proves that God can give, and He can also take back. The message is clear : Let all that we do, all that we accomplish bring glory to God, and not to ourselves. Easier said than done? Signing off, Jenna

When times are tough on us, we tend to lose sight of it all. The world caves in, we lose friends, and it seems like God is a cruel kid on an anthill burning us with a huge magnifying glass. There's no escaping pain in our life. Almost daily we experience misery, loss, rejection, pain, and suffering in various forms and degrees. What we often fail to see is that these experiences are proof of God's love for us. When it all falls apart, we can rest assured that at the very least God has not forsaken us. Only through hardships can we develop into better people. God knows this, and doing His duty as a loving father, he ensures that we experience hardships so that we may grow to be more like Him. The tough part is often continuing to trust in God while we are down, especially since He's in control. We have to remember that it's for our own good, and He's doing this because He loves us very, very much. Lord, get me through this. Your friend, Kevin

I'm going to lift this off Ps Palan's message to my youth on saturday :) We are clay in God's hands. Does the clay tell the potter what shape to mold it into? No, the potter molds the clay exactly as He pleases. The potter knows what shape is best for the clay to be made into, because He knows the texture and type of clay and everything. Sometimes we tell the potter "Make me into this, or make me into that!" If the clay bothers the potter like that, it will only prolong the process. God is like the potter in the passage. If we are marred, He will squash us up, and start again. A vessel/pot/vase is never made perfect in the first round of molding. The potter has to mold the clay, remove the flecks of dust and small little rocks, squash the clay, and start all over again. Each time, the shape will be better than the last.
